awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Incomplete Neutralization: The Loss and Maintenance of Contrast
awd_abstract_narration:
Languages are not always pronounced the way they are written. Over time, the pronunciation of a language changes, but its orthography remains fixed. This poses problems for standardized spelling, language teaching and learning, and even speech recognition technologies, which need to process and convert spoken language into orthographic representations and vice versa. This dissertation addresses the problem of pronunciation change over time, looking specifically at cases where a distinction between two sounds that was previously present and represented orthographically begins to be lost. Changes like this happen gradually, where differences in the acoustics ("acoustic cues") slowly disappear, sometimes without speakers even realizing it. For example, "t" and "d" are different sounds in Dutch, but over time, the difference between "t" and "d" was lost at the ends of words; "bot" (bone) and "bod" (offer) are both pronounced like the English word "bought". This type of sound change, called "neutralization", is not always complete; small but measurable acoustic differences may remain between the two sounds, despite sounding identical to the naked ear. Studies have shown that listeners are able to perceive these differences subconsciously, as they can tell two seemingly-identical words apart (e.g. Dutch "bot" and "bod") at a rate better than chance, even without additional context. It is unknown what causes this incompleteness, how this process unfolds over time, and what social characteristics affect it. Additionally, it is unclear how speakers can tell these sounds apart, and what the necessary acoustics are for distinguishing between them. 

This dissertation will examine two cases of apparently incomplete neutralization in Dutch and Afrikaans. Both languages are losing the distinction between "t" and "d" and between "p" and "b", both word-initially and word-finally, though they are at different stages of the neutralization process. In four experiments, participants will read words and stories that have these consonants, and then listen to the sounds with manipulated acoustics and see if they can tell them apart. As we discover what differences listeners can hear, we are able to understand more about our cognitive capabilities and how social characteristics can affect our speech and hearing. This knowledge can be used to inform speech recognition technologies to better understand variability in speech production. Additionally, we will have a better understanding of language pronunciation change over time, which can help us develop curricula for teaching foreign languages, especially focusing on the link between reading and pronunciation.

por.por_cntn:
Languages are not always pronounced the way they are written. Over time, the pronunciation of a language changes, but its orthography remains fixed. This poses problems for standardized spelling, language teaching and learning, and speech recognition technologies, which need to process and convert spoken language into orthographic representations and vice versa. This dissertation addresses the problem of pronunciation change over time, looking specifically at cases where a distinction between two sounds that was previously present and represented orthographically begins to be lost ("neutralization"). Changes like this happen gradually, where differences in the acoustics ("acoustic cues") slowly disappear, sometimes without speakers even realizing it.

 

This dissertation is a study of incomplete neutralization in Afrikaans and Dutch, two related languages that are both undergoing neutralization at the beginning and end of words, though they are in different stages of this process.  In these languages, in certain positions, "d" and "t" (and other similar pairs of sounds) are beginning to be pronounced identically.  The vocal fold vibration ("voicing") that characterizes "d" and "b" (and other "voiced" consonants) but not "t" and "p" (and other "voiceless" consonants) is disappearing.  The goal of this research is to understand how the neutralization process unfolds over time, focusing on whether the change is complete or ongoing, if other cues (such as pitch or duration) are taking over instead of voicing, and whether social characteristics affect the perception of these neutralizing sounds.

 

Two perception and production experiments were created and run with native speakers of Afrikaans in Potchefstroom, South Africa, and with native speakers of Dutch in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. The results of the experiments ultimately show that the process of neutralization, occurring via changes in acoustic cues, does not happen uniformly. Individual acoustic cues change and neutralize at different rates. Cue changing can also have significant differences by age and gender groups. In both Afrikaans and Dutch, early stages of neutralization showed large differences between age and gender groups, but in later stages of neutralization, these differences collapsed. It appears that in both Afrikaans and Dutch the process is further along in word-final position: fewer cues are used when perceiving these sounds, and speakers are not producing as many differences between cues as they did in previous research. Word-initially, the languages are in different stages of neutralization: Afrikaans is far into the process, and as a result of cue changing, is developing tone. Dutch is at the beginning of this process, so whether or not it will also develop tone remains a question for future research.

 

This new data on neutralization processes in Dutch and Afrikaans contributes more broadly to our understanding of how neutralization happens on a (socio)phonetic level: both on a small scale (comparing data from younger and older participants) and on a larger scale (comparing data from Afrikaans and Dutch). This dissertation also contributes to a larger conversation about phonological voicing. The results of these experiments show that other acoustic dimensions, such as pitch and the duration of the preceding vowel, can also signal phonological voicing. Based on the experimental results, this dissertation proposes a different theoretical framework, cue-based features, for analyzing phonological voicing and modeling sound change over time.

 

These outcomes also have larger implications. By understanding how acoustic cues can contribute to language change, we can make predictions about pronunciation change over time, which can help us develop curricula for teaching foreign languages, especially focusing on the link between reading and pronunciation. The results of this project can also help inform speech recognition technologies. Knowing the patterns of acoustic cues can help the technology improve its accuracy in speech-to-text translations. On a broader level, the results can also inform these technologies about relevant variability in speech production and perception.
